author: Arsene Lupin III
subject: The Anime Encyclopedia has problems. Big ones.
body:
> I was reading the Anime Encyclopedia, and it has a
> nice spread on Lupin, 
> with little-known facts. For one thing, Goemon's
> seiyuu also played Harlock. 
> The original Arsene Lupin's term of expiration is
> suppose dto be 2016.

Maybe. But I heard his copyright expired in 1991,
since he died 50 years before. Since the legal reform
of copyright came after 1995 (sez the "Anime Encyc.),
it doesn't make sense that the change in law should
apply to something that had already left copyright,
unless those Europeans have post de facto
laws....which would just suck.

> Lupin 
> VIII was a French-Japanese co-production.

I thought I mentioned that...about....a year ago on
here.

> They even
> have an anime from Toei 
> called "Lupin vs Holmes", based on the story of the
> same name! Hopefully 
> since Funimation is closely connected with Toei,
> they'll get their hands on 
> that one eventually. :)

Well, Cloverway (think Sailor Moon S/SuperS dubs) IS
Toei America, basically. So it's possible it could
come from them, too.....but not likely.

At any rate, that Encyclopedia has boatloads of facts
WRONG about Lupin III, I'm wondering if I should trust
its info beyond what I know.

Jigen's VA is named "Kiyoshi Kobayashi," not "Kiyoshi
Komori."
The Golden Legend of Babylon was NOT Lupin's final
theatrical anime outing, despite the Encyclopedia's
statements to the contrary. Dead or Alive was. The
Encyc. claims "Die! Nostradamus" and "Dead or Alive"
were both TV movies. Had this woman SEEN them, and
noticed that they were in *letterbox,* perhaps this
error would not have been made.

"Tales of the Wolf": The scripts for these TV episodes
DID include the name "Lupin"....heck, in "Albatross"
he was called "Lupin" half the time! Did she even
notice that the cases and video footage themeselves
say "Lupin III: Tales of the Wolf?" And the second
episode was called "Aloha LUPIN."

The legal dispute Australia sparked was not started
over TV episodes, but the first Lupin anime film,
"Lupin the Third" (a/k/a "Mystery of Mamo"). This
happened back in the late 1970's, and could hardly
have been a reason to make a last minute change to an
English release in 1995!

Golden Legend of Babylon (again): The bike chase was
not "hilarious." But that's a matter of opinion. The
fact is, it did NOT take place in Madison Square
Garden, but on a giant manufactured face that (for
some odd reason) reacts to the characters riding on
it. Heck, the cast never visits Madison Square until
the finale of the film. The buried gold is NOT inside
an alien spaceship, and thanks for mentioning the
semi-surprise ending: there is no God, *aliens* want
the gold. Go figure. It says Lupin misses out on sex
with a space goddess. I don't think she ever implied
she wanted to have sex with Lupin....only that she
loved him.

Die! Nostradamus: At no point in the film did Jigen
and Lupin ever disguise as soccer players. Though once
they did verbally claim to be the managers of the
soccer team, while wearing their regular clothes.

Da Capo of Love-- Fujiko's Unlucky Days: Yes, Fujiko
gives Lupin the loot from the Swiss Bank, and is
interested in the Columbus File/Egg. That sums up
about the first two minutes of the film. The thing is,
Fujiko *memorizes* the file and then immediately gets
amnesia! That's a superb summary of plot point A, And
that's 5 minutes in! While not necessarily an error,
it is yet another sign that the writers did not view
the film.

$1 Money Wars: The woman who bought the ring for a
dollar was Cynthia, not "St. Cyr." How does one get
"St. Cyr" from "Shinshia?"

There's more problems, but I gotta go. More later. ;)
